Summary:	Motor vehicle accidents â compensation â claim for in
terms of
s 17(1)(b)
of the
Road Accident Fund Act 56 of 1996
â
provisions of
s 24(5)
read with
regulation 2(1)(c)
â does failure
of the Fund to object to validity of claim within 60 days render
claim valid in law in all respects â provisions
of
s 24(5)
relating

regulation  2(1)(c)
contains a substantive

JUDGMENT
MLAMBO JA
[1]	The appellant instituted an action for compensation
against the respondent (the Fund) arising from injuries he sustained
in a
motor vehicle collision as contemplated in
s 17(1)(b)
4
>
1
of the
Road Accident Fund Act 56 of 1996
.
[2]	The Fund filed a special plea alleging
non-compliance with the provisions of
s 17(1)(b)
read with
regulation
2(1)(c).
4
>
2
The appellant replicated alleging that he had complied with the
provisions of the regulation; alternatively that he had substantially
complied with the provisions thereof and further alternatively that
the regulation was
ultra vires
the Act.
[3]	The matter come before De Vos J, in the
Pretoria High Court, who dismissed the special plea.
3
She however granted the Fund leave to appeal to this court, which
upheld the appeal and set aside the order she had granted.
4
[4]	This court, in upholding the appeal, observed, with
regard to
s 24(5)
, as follows:
â
It may be that this section could provide an answer
to the special plea. Counsel were unable to make considered
submissions on the
law and the facts are not before the Court. The
defendantâs counsel had no objection to leave being granted to the
plaintiff to
amend his replication, if so advised, to place reliance
on
s 24(5).
That course commends itself for otherwise the plaintiff
may be done an injustice.â
[5]	Based on this observation the appellant was granted
leave to amend his replication to raise the provisions of
s 24(5)
4
>
5
in answer to the special plea. The appellant duly amended his
replication and the special plea was again enrolled for hearing in
the court
a quo
. The
matter became before Els J who upheld the special plea.
6
This appeal is with the leave of that court.
[6]	In upholding the special plea, the court
a
quo
found that the purpose of
s 24(5)
was to
regulate the procedural matters set out in that section and nothing
further. The court found support for this view in
Krischke
v Road Accident Fund
.
7
In that case the court (Jajbhay J) found that the structure of
s 24
entailed procedures for the completion and lodging of a claim form
with the Fund. The purpose of the section was to afford the Fund
sufficient time to consider the claim and to decide whether to
contest or settle it. The learned judge then concluded that
s 24(5)
had no bearing on substantive law, and (in that case) could not be
relied upon to revive a claim that had become prescribed.
[7]	Before us the argument advanced on behalf of the
appellant was essentially that, despite the latterâs non-compliance
with the
requirement in
Regulation 2(1)(c)
, the failure by the Fund
to object to his claim in terms of
s 24(5)
, based on that omission,
as it should have, rendered the claim valid in law in all respects.
[8]	This construction of
s 24(5)
read with
regulation
2(1)(c)
is in my view incorrect.
Regulation 2(1)(c)
prescribes a
substantive requirement to found liability (the submission of an
affidavit to the police) and non-compliance therewith
is fatal. On
the other hand the purpose of
s 24
is to ensure that, before the
onset of litigation, sufficient particulars about the claim are
placed before the Fund to enable it,
timeously, to make a decision
whether it resisted or settled the claim.
8
The section has nothing to do with issues not specified therein.
Simply put it is incapable of breathing life into a claim that failed
to arise because of non-compliance with the substantive requirement
found in
regulation 2(1)(c).
[9]	Appellantâs counsel was unable, correctly in my
view, to advance any basis on which the reasoning in
Krischke
v Road Accident Fund (
supra), which I
embrace, could be faulted. In the result the appeal is dismissed with
costs.

sections.facts: The appellant, Samuel Feli Thugwana, sought compensation from the Road Accident Fund for injuries sustained in a motor‑vehicle collision under s 17(1)(b) of the Road Accident Fund Act. The Fund raised a special plea alleging non‑compliance with regulation 2(1)(c), which requires the third‑party claimant to submit an affidavit to the police within 14 days of being able to do so. The appellant contended that he had either complied, substantially complied, or that the regulation was ultra‑vires. The High Court dismissed the special plea, granted leave to appeal, and the matter eventually returned to the High Court where the special plea was upheld, leading to the present appeal to the Supreme Court of Appeal.
sections.issues: The central issue was whether the failure of the Fund to object to the claim within 60 days under s 24(5) of the Act rendered the claim valid in law despite the appellant’s non‑compliance with the substantive requirement of regulation 2(1)(c). A subsidiary issue concerned whether s 24(5) is a procedural provision only or can affect substantive rights.
sections.principles: Section 24(5) of the Road Accident Fund Act provides that a claim is deemed valid in law if the Fund does not object within 60 days, but the court held that this provision is limited to procedural matters concerning the timing of objections. Regulation 2(1)(c) imposes a substantive condition—submission of a police affidavit—and non‑compliance is fatal to the claim. The Court relied on the earlier decision in Krischke v Road Accident Fund, which affirmed that s 24(5) cannot revive a claim that fails to meet substantive statutory requirements.
sections.application: Applying the principles, the Court concluded that s 24(5) could not cure the appellant’s failure to satisfy the substantive requirement of regulation 2(1)(c). Consequently, the Fund’s special plea of non‑compliance stood, and the appellate court found no basis to overturn the High Court’s ruling in favour of the Fund.
sections.conclusion: The appeal was dismissed with costs. The appellant’s claim was not reinstated, and the Road Accident Fund’s procedural objection under s 24(5) was deemed insufficient to override the substantive non‑compliance with regulation 2(1)(c).
